results.title: Recycling : the endless circle
results.brief_description: The world has a garbage crisis - and every one of us contributes to it, but we can also be part of the solution. This film examines both the problems causing our garbage glut and some of the ways that industries, communities, and individuals are working to solve these problems. The video illustrates how we can reduce, reuse and recycle to bring our solid waste problem under control. The manufacture of an aluminium can is also illustrated. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Recycling
results.creator_credit: Environmental Protection Agency and Stuart Finley
results.brief_description: Shows existing techniques for recovering materials from solid waste and describes the newly developed equipment and systems which may make recycling a universal project in the future. The pressure of public opinion in favour of recycling is enormous, nevertheless it is actually practised very little.

results.title: Recycled reflections
results.brief_description: A non-narrated film which first emphasises the potentially great waste in the single product, automobile bumpers, by exploring the piles of twisted discards. It then follows the process of transforming the damaged bumpers into good-as-new ones. Shows the recycling process from the heavy machines used to straighten the major dents and twists through hand-hammering, grinding, polishing and electro-plating. Finally, the transformed bumpers, indistinguishable from newly made ones, are plastic wrapped and stored awaiting use on new cars.

results.title: Rectangular co-ordinates
results.creator_credit: Loucks and Norling Studios and United States. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Radio Technician Training”.
Demonstrates how to use co-ordination in solving problems involving time and distance, and how to locate a point using two co-ordinates.

results.title: Rectangle & rectangles & rectangle
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Robert Forget and Rene Jodoin
results.brief_description: This is a didactic film in disguise. A progression of brilliant geometric shapes bombard the screen to the insistent beat of drums. The filmmaker programmed a computer to coordinate a highly complex operation involving an electronic beam of light, colour filters and a camera. This animation film, without words, is designed to expose the power of the cinematic medium, and to illustrate the abstract nature of time. Animation by Rene Jodoin with assistance in computer animation by Doris Kochanek and Daniel Langlois. Music score by Normand Roger, sound by Louis Hone.

results.title: Recreation and leisure
results.creator_credit: Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit, Tony Shaddock, Helen Edwards and Tim Abbott
results.brief_description: Designed to assist the intellectual disability residential care worker to appreciate the benefits of recreation and leisure, learn how to develop a recreation and leisure program, develop the skills to instruct residents and learn how to evaluate the success of the program. Accompanied by 31p. in-service training manual. At the conclusion of this program the “No excuses. Life. Be In It” advertisment targeting people with disabilities and featuring an amputee, deaf person and paraplegic is screened.

results.title: Recovering from a coronary
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Geoffrey Scott, Ronald Bowie and Frank Milton
results.brief_description: Demonstrates a practical rehabilitation program for patients with coronary heart disease (devised at Otago University Medical School and the New Zealand School of Physiotherapy) which has produced encouraging results. Although intended mainly for medical audiences, the film offers advice which would well help to avoid or delay the premature onset of coronary heart disease in the population as a whole.
